intro: Cyclaminus coum, commonly known as the Persian violet, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It belongs to the Bignoniaceae family and is characterized by its heart-shaped leaves and showy, violet-blue flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained soil with full sun to partial shade. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Cyclaminus coum is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and botanical collections.
